sp.p: O filial affection, do thou preserve me, since I have carefully preserved thee. Welcome, my brother.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: How am I to believe that? Tell me, if you are speaking the truth, who was your mother?

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: Cleobula.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Who was your nurse?

note.#text: :  Many mishaps appear to have happened to families through the lawlessness and violence of which the Festivals of the Divinities were the occasion.
:  Suetonius tells us that the reign of Tiberius was rendered memorable by the fall of the scaffolding in the theatre of Fiden.

p.#text: Archestrata. Amid the sacred rites of Bacchus she had carried me to see the sights * * * * * * * after we had come thither, when now she had found me a place, a whirlwind arose; the scaffolding of the stage there tumbled down; I was greatly alarmed, and then some one, I know not who, seized hold of me trembling and frightened, neither alive nor dead; and in what manner he carried me off I cannot say.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I recollect that disturbance happening; but, do you tell me, where is this person, who carried you away?

p.#text: I know not; but  this ring I have all along preserved by me, with it long since was I lost.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Give it me to look at.

p.#text: . Are you in your senses to be trusting it to that fellow?
Do you only leave me alone.
. O Jupiter! This is the same that I presented you upon your birthday; I recognize it as easily as my own self. Welcome to you, my sister.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: My brother, welcome to you.

sp.speaker: PHD.
sp.p: I trust the Gods will prosper this matter for you.

p.#text: And I, for all of us.  Do you, as having this day arrived, give a dinner in honor of your sister he , to-morrow, will give one in honor of his marriage; we promise that.
. Do you hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: I shan't hold my tongue, as things are turning out so well. Captain, do you promise her to him; I'll give the marriage-portion.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What is the marriage-portion?

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: What, that I give? Why, that always as long as he lives he's to feed me.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I' troth, he says what's fair; with my consent you shall do so. But this Procurer owes me the thirty min.

sp.speaker: PHD.
sp.p: For what reason so?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Because he agreed with me on these terms to give it back: that if any one should assert her to be free born in due course of law, he would, without dispute, pay back all the money.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: Then let's go to the Procurer.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: PHD.
sp.p: This first I wish; to despatch my matter.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What's that?

p.#text: That you will betroth her to me.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: Why do you hesitate, Captain, to give her as a wife to him?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: If she is agreable.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: My brother, it is my wish.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: So be it then.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: You do rightly.

sp.speaker: PHD.
sp.p: Captain, do you betroth me to her for my wife?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I do betroth her.

p.#text: . And to him do I promise support at my expense.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: You do kindly. But * * * * * * * *

note.#text: :  In allusion to the money which he intends to have back from the Procurer. "Thesaurum" seems here to have the signification of "treasurer" or "treasury."

p.#text: * * * * * But see, here's the Procurer coming; my treasurer, I mean.

note.#text: :  This and the following line are clearly in a very corrupt state. Indeed, it is hard to gather any sense whatever from them.

:  He seems to mean, that, where there is no possibility of the debtor paying back the money, the case is more fortunate than where you are tormented by hopes of getting it back, which, however, are doomed to disappointment.
:  He was afraid that Lyco would cheat him, by filing his schedule, or taking the benefit, in the Roman style. See the Note to l. 373 (Act III., Sc. 1).

p.#text: . Those who say it's bad for bankers to be trusted, utter nonsense; I say it's neither good nor bad for them to be trusted, and that, I've fully experienced this day. They are not badly trusted, who never repay, but with whom it is lost outright. As for example, before this Lyco paid me the ten min, he had to go to every banker's counter. After there were no proceeds, I summoned the fellow with much noise; he appealed against me to the court. I was most confoundedly afraid that this day he'd be settling accounts with me before the Prtor; but my friends forced him, so he paid the money at home. Now I'm resolved to make haste to my house.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Hallo! you Procurer; I want you.

sp.speaker: PHD.
sp.p: And I want you.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: But I don't want either of you.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Stay this instant, will you.

sp.speaker: PHD.
sp.p: And make you haste to disgorge the money with all despatch.

p.#text: . What have you to do with me?  Or what have you?

note.#text: :  "Nervus," "a cord," was also the name of the iron chain fastened round the neck and legs of the prisoner. If the debtor did not pay within thirty days after judgment, lie was liable to be thrown into prison by the creditor.

p.#text: Because this day I shall be making a javelin of you, discharged from a catapulta, and twist you with the string, just as the catapultas are in the habit of doing.

note.#text: :  He jokes on the double meaning of the word "catellus," which signified "an iron chain," and also "a little dog."

p.#text: I'll this day make a coxcomb of you, to be sleeping with a puppy in your bed--an iron one, I mean.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: But I'll make you both to be rotting in a strong-barred prison.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Seize him by the throat, and away with him to extreme torture.

p.#text: However that is, he'll be going there of his own accord.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: O Gods and men, your aid! that I, uncondemned, and without evidence against me, should thus be dragged along! Prithee, Planesium, and you, Phdromus, do give me assistance.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: Brother, I do beseech you, don't ruin him uncondemned; he treated me kindly and modestly at his house.

note.#text: :  Who had not granted him convalescence so soon as he desired.

p.#text: That was through no inclination of his own; give you thanks to this sculapius  that you've preserved your chastity; for if he had been well, he'd long ago have packed you off wherever he could.

Now attend to me, both of you, if I can arrange between you.  You let him go. Procurer, come you this way. I'll pronounce my opinion, if indeed you are ready to abide by what I shall decide you should do.

p.stage: He lets go of the PROCURER.
p.#text: We leaves it to you.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: So long, i' faith, as you give a decision to the effect that no one is to take the money away from me.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What, not that which you promised?

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: I, promised? How?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: With your tongue.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: With that same tongue I now gainsay it; that was given me by Nature for the purpose of speaking, not of losing my property.

p.#text: He's trifling; seize the fellow by the throat.  CAP. I'll at once then do as you bid me.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Since you are an honest man, answer me this that I ask you.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: Ask me what you please.

p.#text: Did you not promise, that if any one should show that she  was freeborn, you would pay back all the money?

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: I don't remember saying so.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What, do you deny it?

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: I' faith, I really do deny it. In whose presence? In what place was it?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: In my own presence, and that of Lyco the banker.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: Why don't you hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I shan't hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: I don't care a rush for you; don't be bullying me.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: In my own presence and that of Lyco it took place.

p.#text: . I quite believe you. Now, therefore, Procurer, that you may know my judgment,  she is a free woman; he  is her brother, and she is his sister; she is engaged to me; do you restore him the money; that's my decision.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: Upon my faith, Phdromus, you have given this decision corruptly. It shall both be bad for you, and you, Captain,--may the Gods and Goddesses confound you.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: And as for you, you shall be clapt in prison at once, unless the money's returned me.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: Then follow me.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Follow you where?

note.#text: :  See the Note to l. 684.

p.#text: To my banker--to the Prtor; for it's there that I pay my money to all persons to whom I'm indebted.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I'll be carrying you hence to prison, and not to the Prtor, if you don't pay back the money.

note.#text: :  "Ne me nescias." Equivalent to our phrase, "I fully give you to understand."

p.#text: I do most earnestly wish you may come to a bad end, so don't misunderstand me.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Do you really so?

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: I' faith, I really do so.

p.#text: I don't misunderstand these fists of mine.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What then, do you ask? With these same fists, if you provoke me, I'll be making you quiet immediately.

p.stage: taking the money from his girdle
p.#text: . Well then, take this back at once.
. By all means.

sp.speaker: PHD.
sp.p: Captain, you'll dine with me; the nuptials shall take place to-day.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: May this matter turn out well for me and for yourselves.
Spectators, give us your applause.
